bibl.title: Letter from David L. Edsall to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 9, 1924

div1.p: Edsall requests Kissinger's address. A fund has been established in his name, Harvard University Medical School, which would provide a pension to Ida Kissinger upon John Kissinger's death.

div1.head: Letter from David L. Edsall to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 9, 1924
div1.opener:
COPY
December 9, 1924
Col. Jefferson R. Kean, U.S.A. Retired,
Library of the Surgeon General,
7th and B Streets, S. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
At the suggestion of Colonel William J. L. H. Lyster,
Professor of Military Science and Tactics, I am writing to
ask whether you can advise me how to proceed to find the
present whereabouts and circumstances of Mrs. Ida E. Kissinger,
wife of John R. Kissinger.

A gift left to the Medical School and known as the
John R. Kissinger Fund carries the provision that if the wife
of John R. Kissinger survive him and is in pecuniary need,
$45. a month may be paid to her from the fund while such
pecuniary want exists.

John R. Kissinger, a Private, U. S. Army, volunteered
for yellow fever inoculation on December 5, 1900. He received
a pension from the United States Government of $100. a month
from 1911. Our last known address for Mrs. Kissinger was in
1911---810 Milton Avenue, South Bend, Indiana.

I should be very grateful if you could advise me how
to proceed in tracing Mrs. Kissinger.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, David L. Edsall
Dean R:MM
